verses.text: The proverbs of Solomon, son of David, king of Israel:
verses.comment: Proverbs is traditionally attributed to Solomon, renowned for his wisdom. These sayings are teachings of practical and spiritual guidance.

verses.text: To know wisdom and instruction, to understand words of insight,
verses.comment: The purpose of Proverbs is set forth: to impart true wisdom that shapes both heart and mind.

verses.text: to receive instruction in wise behavior, righteousness, justice, and integrity;
verses.comment: Wisdom includes moral living. Righteousness, justice, and uprightness are emphasized as results of a well-formed conscience and actions.

verses.text: to give prudence to the simple, knowledge and discretion to the youth—
verses.comment: God's wisdom is for all, especially the simple and the young, providing the foundation for growth in virtue.

verses.text: Let the wise hear and increase in learning, and the one who understands obtain guidance,
verses.comment: Even the wise benefit from humility and continued growth in wisdom. Wisdom is a lifelong pursuit.

verses.text: to understand a proverb and a saying, the words of the wise and their riddles.
verses.comment: Wisdom often comes in parables and riddles requiring careful meditation—anticipating how Jesus taught in parables. See Matthew 13:34.

verses.text: The fear of the LORD is the beginning of knowledge; fools despise wisdom and instruction.
verses.comment: Reverence for God is the foundation of all wisdom, connecting fear of the Lord with obedience and humility. For spiritual interpretation, see Prov. 8:13.

verses.text: Hear, my son, your father’s instruction, and do not forsake your mother’s teaching,
verses.comment: Respect for parental authority points to an ordered family and the spiritual role of obedience to tradition and sound teaching handed down.

verses.text: for they are a garland of grace for your head and pendants for your neck.
verses.comment: Obedience brings honor and spiritual beauty. The image signifies that virtue adorns a person more than external jewelry.

verses.text: My son, if sinners entice you, do not consent.
verses.comment: The warning assumes the presence of temptation and stresses personal moral choice—resist evil companions.

verses.text: If they say, 'Come with us, let us lie in wait for blood; let us ambush the innocent without reason;
verses.comment: Sinners lure others into violent acts. The innocent imagery echoes Christ as the ultimately innocent victim.

verses.text: Let us swallow them alive like the grave, whole, like those who go down to the pit;
verses.comment: Sin’s violence mirrors the destructive power of the grave (Sheol). This alludes spiritually to the consequences of separation from God’s life.

verses.text: we shall find all precious goods, we shall fill our houses with plunder;
verses.comment: Ill-gotten gain is condemned. Greed corrupts the soul—this warning anticipates Jesus' teaching in Luke 12:15.

verses.text: throw in your lot among us; we will all have one purse.”
verses.comment: Sin loves company, and communal wrongdoing multiplies guilt. The lure of 'one purse' suggests a counterfeit unity.

verses.text: My son, do not walk in the way with them; restrain your foot from their path,
verses.comment: A clear call to separate from the sinful. This foreshadows New Testament teaching, e.g., 2 Cor. 6:14.

verses.text: for their feet run to evil, and they hurry to shed blood.
verses.comment: Those seduced by sin are relentless in wrongdoing. This is echoed as a mark of the wicked in Old and New Testament.

verses.text: For in vain is a net spread in the sight of any bird,
verses.comment: The foolishness of sinners: even animals avoid obvious traps, but the wicked choose willfully.

verses.text: but these men lie in wait for their own blood; they set an ambush for their own lives.
verses.comment: Those who seek harm for others ultimately endanger themselves—a principle of moral order underlying creation.

verses.text: Such are the ways of everyone who is greedy for unjust gain; it takes away the life of its possessors.
verses.comment: Greed is destructive—ultimately, those who seek riches at any cost lose their souls.

verses.text: Wisdom cries aloud in the street, in the markets she raises her voice;
verses.comment: Wisdom is personified, present in public life, calling all to conversion. Some Church Fathers see Wisdom here as a foreshadowing of Christ and the Spirit.

verses.text: at the head of the noisy streets she calls out; at the entrance of the city gates she speaks:
verses.comment: The gates are where justice is carried out (Deut. 16:18). Wisdom seeks to shape public and personal life.

verses.text: "How long, you simple ones, will you love simplicity? How long will scoffers delight in their scoffing and fools hate knowledge?
verses.comment: A call to conversion addresses all: simple, scoffers, fools must turn and seek truth.

verses.text: If you turn at my reproof, behold, I will pour out my spirit to you; I will make my words known to you.
verses.comment: Promise of the Spirit for those who repent—foresees the outpouring fulfilled at Pentecost (Acts 2). Spiritual wisdom is a gift received in humility.

verses.text: Because I called and you refused to listen, stretched out my hand and no one paid attention,
verses.comment: God's call extended, yet many refuse. Parallels Jesus’ lament over Jerusalem’s rejection (Matt. 23:37).

verses.text: because you have ignored all my counsel and would have none of my correction,
verses.comment: Free will is respected; a person can reject God’s guidance. Highlights the seriousness of heeding or rejecting divine instruction.

verses.text: I also will laugh at your disaster; I will mock when dread comes upon you,
verses.comment: Righteous judgment: if wisdom is spurned, justice follows. Perspective ties to God’s sovereignty.

verses.text: when terror strikes you like a storm and your calamity comes like a whirlwind, when distress and anguish come upon you.
verses.comment: Ignoring wisdom results in inevitable disaster.

verses.text: Then they will call upon me, but I will not answer; they will seek me diligently but will not find me.
verses.comment: There is a time when repentance is too late—rejecting wisdom brings consequences. See also the parable of the ten virgins in Matt. 25:11-12.

verses.text: Because they hated knowledge and did not choose the fear of the LORD,
verses.comment: Repeats the theme: rejecting the fear of God is the root of folly.

verses.text: would have none of my counsel and despised all my correction,
verses.comment: Lack of teachability is a central mark of foolishness; openness to correction shows humility—a major spiritual virtue.

verses.text: therefore they shall eat the fruit of their way and be filled with their own schemes.
verses.comment: Sin’s consequence: we reap what we sow—a biblical theme connecting to both Testaments.

verses.text: For the turning away of the simple kills them, and the complacency of fools destroys them;
verses.comment: Complacency is the silent engine of destruction: spiritual laziness is a grave danger.

verses.text: but whoever listens to me will dwell secure and will be at ease, without dread of disaster.”
verses.comment: Wisdom brings true safety and peace. Spiritual listening and obedience to divine revelation are at the heart of salvation and life with God.
